3 O woful day!
4 O Traitors, Villains!
1. O moſt bloody ſight!
2. We will be reveng'd: Revenge
About, ſeek, burn, fire, kill, ſlay,
Let not a Traitor live.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stay Countrymen.
1. Peace there, hear the Noble Antony.
2. We'll hear him, we'll follow him, we'll die with him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good Friends, ſweet Friends, let me not ſtir you up.
To ſuch a ſudden Flood of Mutiny:
They that have done this Deed, are Honourable.
What private griefs they have, alas I know not,
That made them do it: They are Wiſe, and Honourable,
And will no doubt with Reaſons anſwer you.
I come not (Friends) to ſteal away your hearts,
I am no Orator, as Brutus is;
But (as you know me all) a plain blunt man
That love my Friend, and that they know full well,
That gave me publick leave to ſpeak of him;
For I have neither writ nor words, nor worth,
Action, nor Utterance, nor the power of Speech,
To ſtir mens Blood. I only ſpeak right on:
I tell you that, which you your ſelves do know,
Shew you ſweet Caeſars wounds, poor, poor dumb mouths
And bid them ſpeak for me: But were I Brutus,
And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony,
Would ruffle up your Spirits, and put a Tongue
In every wound of Caeſar, that ſhould move
That ſtones of Rome, to riſe and Mutiny.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We'll Mutiny.
1 We'll burn the houſe of Brutus.
3 Away then, come, ſeek the Conſpirators.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yet hear me Countrymen, yet hear me ſpeak.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Peace ho, hear Antony, moſt Noble Antony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why Friends, you go to do you know not what:
Wherein hath Caeſar thus deſerv'd your loves?
Alas you know not, I muſt tell you then:
You have forgot the Will I told you of.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Moſt true, the Will, let's ſtay and hear the Will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here is the Will, and under Caeſars Seal:
To every Roman Citizen he gives,
To every ſeveral man, ſeventy five Drachmaes.

sp.speaker: 2 Ple.
sp.l: Moſt Noble Caeſar, we'll revenge his death.

sp.speaker: 3 Ple.
sp.l: O Royal Caeſar▪

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hear me with patience.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Peace ho.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Moreover, he hath left you all his Walks,
His private Arbors, and new-planted Orchards,
On this ſide Tyber, he hath left them you,
And to your Heirs for ever: common pleaſures
To walk abroad, and Recreate your ſelves.
Here was a Caeſar: when comes ſuch another?

sp.speaker: 1. Ple.
sp.l: Never, never: come, away, away:
We'll burn his body in the Holy Place,
And with the Brands fire the Traitors houſes.
Take up the Body.

sp.speaker: 2. Ple.
sp.l: Go fetch fire.

sp.speaker: 3. Ple.
sp.l: Pluck down Benches.

sp.speaker: 4. Ple.
sp.l: Pluck down Forms, Windows, any thing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now let it work: Miſchief thou art a foot,
Take thou what courſe thou wilt.
How now Fellow?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He and Lepidus are at Caeſars houſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And thither will I ſtraight, to viſit him:
He comes upon a wiſh. Fortune is merry,
And in this mood will give us any thing.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I heard him ſay, Brutus and Cassius
Are rid like Madmen through the Gates of Rome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Belike they had ſome notice of the People,
How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius.

div.stage: Enter Cinna the Poet, and after him the Plebeians.

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.l: I dreamt to night, that I did feaſt with Caeſar.
And things unluckily charge my Fantaſie:
I have no will to wander forth of doors,
Yet ſomething leads me Forth.
1. What is your yame?
2. Whether are you going?
3. Where do you dwell?
4. Are you a married Man or a Batchellor?
2. Anſwer every man directly.
1. I, and briefly.
4. I, and wiſely.
3. I, and truly, you were beſt.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: What is my Name? Whither am I going? Where do I w • ll? Am I a married man or a Batchellour? Then to anſwer every Man, directly and briefly, wiſely and truly: wiſely I ſay, I am a Batchellor.
2. That's as much as to ſay, they are Foors that marry: you'll bear me a Bang for that I fear: proceed directly.

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.l: Directly I am going to Caeſar's Funeral.
1. As a Friend, or an Enemy?

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.l: As a Friend.
2. That matter is anſwered directly.
4. For your dwelling; briefly.

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.l: Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.
3. Your Name Sir, truly.

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.l: Truly, my Name is Cinna.
1. Tear him to pieces, he's a Conſpirator.

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.l: I am Cinna the Poet, I am Cinna the Poet.
4. Tear him for his bad Verſes, tear him for his bad Verſes.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.l: I am not Cinna the Conſpirator.
sp.p: 4. It is no matter, his name's Cinna, pluck but his Name out of his Heart, and turn him going.
3. Tear him, tear him; Come, Brands ho, Firebrands: to Brutus, to Caſſius, burn all. Some to Decius Houſe, and ſome to Caska's; ſome to Ligarius. Away, go.

div.head: Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Theſe many then ſhall dye, their Names are prick'd.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Your Brother too muſt dye; conſent you Lepidus?

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: I do conſent.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Prick him down Antony.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Upon Condition Publius ſhall not live,
Who is your Siſters Son, Mark Antony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He ſhall not live; look, with a Spot I dam him,
But Lepidus, go you to Caeſar's houſe:
Fetch the Will hither, and we ſhall determine
How to cut off ſome charge in Legacies.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: What? ſhall I find you here?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Or here, or at the Capitol.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is a ſlight unmeritable man,
Meet to be ſent on Errands: is it fit
The three-fold World divided, he ſhould ſtand
One of the three to ſhare it?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: So you thought him,
And took his Voice who ſhould be prick'd to dye
In our black Sentence and Proſcription

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Octavius, I have ſeen more days than you;
And though we lay theſe Honours on this Man,
To eaſe our ſelves of divers ſtand'rous Lords,
He ſhall but bear them, as the Aſs bears Gold,
To groan and ſweat under the Buſineſs,
Either led or driven, as we point the way:
And having brought our Treaſure, where we will,
Then take we down his Load, and turn him off
(Like to the empty Aſs) to ſhake his Ears,
And graze in Commons.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: You may do your Will:
But he's a tryed, and valiant Souldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So is my Horſe Octavius, and for that
I do appoint him ſtore of Provender.
It is a Creature that I teach to fight,
To wind, to ſtop, to run directly on:
His corporal motion, govern'd by my Spirit,
And in ſome taſte, is Lepidus but ſo:
He muſt be taught, and train'd, and bid go forth:
A barren ſpirited Fellow; one that feeds
On Objects, Arts, and Imitations.
Which out of uſe, and ſtal'd by other men
Begin his Faſhion. Do not talk of him,
But as a Property: and now Octavius,
Liſten great things. Brutus and Caſſius
Are levying Powers; We muſt ſtraight make head:
Therefore let our Alliance be combin'd,
Our beſt Friends made, our means ſtretch'd,
And let us preſently go ſit in Councel,
How covert matters may be beſt diſclos'd,
And open Perils ſureſt anſwered.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Let us do ſo: for we are at the Stake,
And bayed about with many Enemies,
And ſome that ſmile have in their Hearts I fear
Millions of miſchiefs.

div.stage: Drum. Enter Brutus, Lucillius, and the Army. Titinius and Pindarus meet them.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Stand ho.

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: Give the Word ho, and ſtand.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: What now Lucillius, is Caſſius near?

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: He is at hand, and Pindarus is come
To do you Salutation from his Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: He greets me well. Your Maſter Pindarus▪
In his own Change, or by ill Officers,
Hath given me ſome worthy cauſe to wiſh,
Things done, undone: But if he be at hand
I ſhall be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I do not doubt
But that my Noble Maſter will appear
Such as he is, full of Regard and Honour.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: He is not doubted. A word Lucillius
How he receiv'd you: let me be reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: With Courteſie, and with Reſpect enough,
But not with ſuch familiar Inſtances,
Nor with ſuch free and friendly Conference
As he hath us'd of old.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Thou haſt deſcrib'd
A hot Friend, cooling: Ever note Lucillius,
When Love begins to ſicken and decay
It uſeth an enforced Ceremony.
There are no Tricks, in plain and ſimple Faith:
But hollow men, like Horſes hot at hand,
Make gallant ſhew, and promiſe of their Mettle:
But when they ſhould endure the bloody Spur,
They fall their Creſts, and like deceitful Jades
Sink in the Tryal. Comes his Army on?

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: They mean this Night in Sardis to be quarter'd:
The greater part, the Horſe in general
Are come with Caſſius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Hark, he is arriv'd;
March gently on to meet him.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Stand ho.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Stand ho, ſpeak the Word along.
Stand.
Stand.
Stand.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Moſt Noble Brother, you have done me wrong.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Judge me you Gods; wrong I mine Enemies?
And if not ſo, how ſhould I wrong a Brother?

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Brutus, this ſober Form of yours hides Wrongs,
And when you do them—

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Caſſius, be content.
Speak your griefs ſoftly, I do know you well.
Before the Eyes of both our Armies here
(Which ſhould perceive nothing but Love from us)
Let us not wrangle. Bid them move away:
Then in my Tent Caſſius enlarge your Griefs,
And I will give you Audience.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Pindarus,
Bid our Commanders lead their Charges off
A little from this Ground.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucillius, do you the like, and let no Man
Come to our Tent, till we have done our Conference.
Let Lucius and Titinius guard our door.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: That you have wrong'd me, doth appear in this:
You have condemn'd, and noted Lucius Pella
For taking Bribes here of the Sardians;
Wherein my Letters, praying on his ſide,
Becauſe I knew the Man was ſlighted off.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You wrong'd your ſelf to write in ſuch a Caſe.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: In ſuch a time as this, it is not meet
That every nice Offence ſhould bear his Comment.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Let me tell you Caſſius, you your ſelf
Are much condemn'd to have an itching Palm,
To ſell, and mart your Offices for Gold
To Undeſervers.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: I an itching Palm?
You know that you are Brutus that ſpeaks this,
Or by the Gods, this Speech were elſe your laſt.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: The Name of Caſſius honours this Corruption,
And Chaſtiſement doth therefore hide his Head.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Chaſtiſement?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Remember March, the Ides of March remember:
Did not great Julius bleed for Juſtice ſake?
What Villain touch'd his Body, that did ſtab,
And not for Juſtice? What? Shall one of Us,
That ſtruck the fore-moſt man of all this World,
But for ſupporting Robbers; ſhall we now,
Contaminate our Fingers, with baſe Bribes?
And ſell the mighty ſpace of our large Honours
For ſo much Traſh, as may be graſped thus?
I had rather be a Dog, and bay the Moon,
Than ſuch a Roman.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Brutus, bait not me,
I'll not indure it: you forget your ſelf
To hedge me in. I am a Souldier, I,
Older in Practice, abler than your ſelf
To make Conditions.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Go too: you are not Caſſius.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I ſay, you are not.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Urge me no more, I ſhall forget my ſelf;
Have mind upon your Health: Tempt me no farther.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Away ſlight man.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Hear me, for I will ſpeak.
Muſt I give way and room to your raſh Choler?
Shall I be frighted when a Mad-man ſtares?

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: O ye Gods, ye Gods, Muſt I endure all this?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: All this? I more: Fret till your proud Heart break.
Go ſhew your Slaves how cholerick you are,
And make your Bondmen tremble. Muſt I bow?
Muſt I obſerve you? Muſt I ſtand and crouch
Under your teſty Humour? By the Gods,
You ſhall digeſt the Venom of your Spleen
Though it do ſplit you. For, from this day forth,
I'll uſe you for my Mirth, yea for my Laughter
When you are Waſpiſh.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Is it come to this?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You ſay, you are a better Souldier:
Let it appear ſo; make your vaunting true,
And it ſhall pleaſe me well. For mine own part,
I ſhall be glad to learn of Noble-men.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: You wrong me every way:
You wrong me Brutus:
I ſaid, an Elder Souldier, not a Better.
Did I ſay Better?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: If you did, I care not.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: When Caeſar liv'd, he durſt not thus have mov'd me.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Peace, Peace, you durſt not ſo have tempted him.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: I durſt not?

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: What? durſt not tempt him?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: For your Life you durſt not.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Do not preſume too much upon my Love,
I may do that I ſhall be ſorry for.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You have done that you ſhould be ſorry for.
There is no Terror Caſſius in your Threats:
For I am arm'd ſo ſtrong in Honeſty,
That they paſs by me, as the idle Wind,
Which I reſpect not. I did ſend to you
For certain Sums of Gold, which you deny'd me,
For I can raiſe no money by vile means:
By Heaven, I had rather coin my Heart,
And drop my Blood for Drachmaes, than to wring
From the hard hands of Peaſants, their vile Traſh
By any Indirection. I did ſend
To you for Gold to pay my Legions,
Which you deny'd me: was that done like Caſſius?
Should I have anſwer'd Caius Caſſius ſo?
When Marcus Brutus grows ſo covetous,
To lock ſuch Raſcal Counters from his Friends,
Be ready Gods with all your Thunder-bolts,
Daſh him to pieces.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: I deny'd you not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You did.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: I did not. He was but a Fool
That brought my Anſwer back. Brutus hath riv'd my heart:
A Friend ſhould bear his Friends Infirmities;
But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I do not, till you practice them on me.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: You love me not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I do not like your Faults.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: A friendly Eye could never ſee ſuch Faults.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: A Flatterers would not, though they do appear
As huge as high Olympus.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Come Antony, and young Octavius come,
Revenge your ſelves alone on Caſſius,
For Caſſius is a-weary of the World:
Hated by one he loves, brav'd by his Brother,
Cheek'd like a Bond-man, all his Faults obſerv'd;
Set in a Note-Book, learn'd, and con'd by roat
To caſt into my Teeth. O I could weep
My Spirit from mine Eyes. There is my Dagger,
And here my naked Breaſt: Within, a Heart
Dearer than Pluto's Mine, richer than Gold:
If that thou bee'ſt a Roman, take it forth.
I that deny'd thee Gold, will give my Heart;
Strike as thou did'ſt at Caeſar; For I know,
When thou didſt hate him worſt, thou loved'ſt him better
Than ever thou loved'ſt Caſsius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Sheath your Dagger:
Be angry when you will, it ſhall have Scope:
Do what you will, Diſhonour ſhall be Humour.
O Caſſius, you are yoaked with a Lamb
That carries Anger, as the Flint bears Firo,
Who much inforced, ſhews a haſty Spark,
And ſtrait is cold agen.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Hath Caſſius liv'd
To be but Mirth and Laughter to his Brutus,
When Grief and Blood ill temper'd, vexeth him?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: When I ſpoke that, I was ill temper'd too.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Do you confeſs ſo much? Give me your Hand.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: And my Heart too.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: O Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Have not you Love enough to bear with me,
When that raſh Humour which my Mother gave me
Makes me forgetful?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Yes Caſſius, and from henceforth
When you are over-earneſt with your Brutus,
He'll think your Mother chides, and leave you ſo.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Let me go in to ſee the Generals,
There is ſome Grudge between 'em; 'tis not meet
They be alone.

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: You ſhall not come to them.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Nothing but Death ſhall ſtay me.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: How now? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: For ſhame you Generals; what do you mean?
Love, and be Friends, as two ſuch Men ſhould be,
For I have ſeen more years I'm ſure than ye.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Ha, ha, how vilely doth this Cynick rhyme?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Get you hence Sirrah: Sawcy Fellow, hence.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Bear with him Brutus, 'tis his Faſhion.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I'll know his humour, when he knows his time:
What ſhould the Wars do with theſe Jigging Fools?
Companion, hence.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Away, away, be gone.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucillius and Titinius bid the Commanders
Prepare to lodge their Companies to night.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: And come your ſelves, and bring Meſſala with you
Immediately to us.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucius, a Bowl of Wine.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: I did not think you could have been ſo angry.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O Caſſius, I am ſick of many Griefs.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Of your Philoſophy you make no uſe,
If you give place to accidental Evils.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: No man bears Sorrow better. Portia is dead.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Ha? Portia?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: She is dead.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: How ſcap'd I killing, when I croſt you ſo?
O inſupportable and touching loſs!
Upon what Sickneſs?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Impatient of my abſence.
And grief, that young Octavius with Mark Antony,
Have made themſelves ſo ſtrong: For with her death
That Tydings came. With this ſhe fell diſtract,
And (her Attendants abſent) ſwallow'd fire.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: And dy'd ſo?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Even ſo.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: O ye Immortal Gods!

div.stage: Enter Boy with Wine and Tapers.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Speak no more of her: Give me a Bowl of Wine,
In this I bury all Unkindneſs Caſſius.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: My heart is thirſty for that noble pledge.
Fill Lucius, till the Wine o're-ſwell the Cup:
I cannot drink too much of Brutus Love.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Come in Titinius:
Welcome good Meſſala;
Now ſit we cloſe about this Taper here,
And call in queſtion our Neceſſities.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Portia, art thou gone?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: No more I pray you.
Meſſala, I have here received Letters,
That young Octavius, and Mark Antony,
Come down upon us with a mighty Power,
Bending their Expedition toward Philippi.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: My ſelf have Letters of the ſelf-ſame Tenure.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: With what Addition?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: That by Proſcription, and bills of Outlary,
Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus,
Have put to death an hundred Senators.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Therein our Letters do not well agree;
Mine ſpeak of ſeventy Senators that dy'd
By their Proſcriptions, Cicero being one.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Cicero one?

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Cicero is dead, and by that order of Proſcription
Had you your Letters from your Wife, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: No Meſſala.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Nor nothing in your Letters writ of her?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nothing Meſſala.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: That methinks is ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why ask you?
Hear you ought of her in yours?

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Now as you are a Roman tell me true.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Then like a Roman, bear the Truth I tell,
For certain ſhe is dead, and by ſtrange manner.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why farewel Portia: We muſt dye Meſſala:
With meditating that ſhe muſt dye once,
I have the Patience to endure it now.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Even ſo great Men great Loſſes ſhould endure.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: I have as much of this in Art as you,
But yet my Nature could not bear it ſo.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well, to our Work alive. What do you think
Of marching to Philippi preſently?

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: I do not think it good.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Your reaſon?

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: This it is:
'Tis better that the Enemy ſeek us,
So ſhall he waſte his Means, weary his Souldiers,
Doing himſelf offence, whilſt we lying ſtill,
Are full of Reſt, Defence, and Nimbleneſs.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Good Reaſons muſt of force give place to better:
The People 'twixt Philippi and this Ground,
Do ſtand but in a forc'd affection:
For they have grudg'd us Contribution.
The Enemy, marching along by them,
By them ſhall make a fuller number up,
Come on refreſh'd, new added, and encourag'd:
From which advantage ſhall we cut him off.
If at Philippi we do face him there,
Theſe People at our back.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Hear me good Brother.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Under your pardon. You muſt note beſide,
That we have try'd the utmoſt of our Friends:
Our Legions are brim full, our Cauſe is ripe,
The Enemy encreaſeth every day,
We at the height, are ready to decline.
There is a Tide in the Affairs of Men,
Which taken at the Flood, leads on to Fortune;
Omitted, all the Voyage of their Life
Is bound in Shallows, and in Miſeries.
On ſuch a full Sea are we now a-float,
And we muſt take the Current when it ſerves,
Or loſe our Ventures.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Then with your Will go on: we'll along
Our ſelves, and meet them at Philippi.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: The deep of Night is crept upon our Talk,
And Nature muſt obey Neceſſity,
Which we will niggard with a little Reſt:
There is no more to ſay.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: No more, good night,
Early to morrow will we riſe, and hence.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucius, my Gown: farewel good Meſſala,
Good night Titinius; Noble, Noble Caſſius,
Good night, and good repoſe.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: O my dear Brother;
This was an ill beginning of the Night;
Never come ſuch Diviſion 'tween our Souls:
Let it not Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Every thing is well.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Good night my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Good night good Brother.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Meſſa. Good night Lord Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Farewel every one.
Give me the Gown. Where is thy Inſtrument?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Here in the Tent.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: What, thou ſpeak'ſt drowſily;
Poor Knave, I blame thee not, thou art o're-watch'd.
Call Claudio, and ſome other of my Men,
I'll have them ſleep on Cuſhions in my Tent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Varrus, and Claudio?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Calls my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I pray you Sirs, lye in my Tent and ſleep,
It may be I ſhall raiſe you by and by
On buſineſs to my Brother Caſſius.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: So pleaſe you, we will ſtand,
And watch your Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I will not have it ſo: Lye down good Sirs,
It may be I ſhall otherwiſe bethink me.
Look Lucius, here's the Book I ſought for ſo:
I put it in the Pocket of my Gown.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I was ſure your Lordſhip did not give it me.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Bear with me, good Boy, I am much forgetful.
Canſt thou hold up thy heavy eyes a while,
And touch thy Inſtrument a Strain or two.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I my Lord, an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: It does, my Boy:
I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is my Duty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: I ſhould not urge thy Duty paſt thy Might,
I know young Bloods look for a time of reſt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have ſlept my Lord already.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: It was well done, and thou ſhalt ſleep again:
I will not hold thee long. If I do live,
I will be good to thee.
This is a ſleepy Tune: O murd'rous Slumber!
Layeſt thou thy leaden Mace upon my Boy,
That plays thee Muſick? Gentle Knave good night:
I will not do thee ſo much wrong to wake thee:
If thou do'ſt nod, thou break'ſt thy Inſtrument,
I'll take it from thee, and (good Boy) good night.
Let me ſee, let me ſee; is not the Leaf turn'd down
Where I left reading? Here it is, I think.
How ill this Taper burns. Ha! Who comes here?
I think it is the weakneſs of mine Eyes
That ſhapes this monſtrous Apparition.
It comes upon me: Art thou any thing?
Art thou ſome God, ſome Angel, or ſome Devil,
That mak'ſt my Blood cold, and my Hair to ſtare?
Speak to me, what thou art.

sp.speaker: Ghoſt.
sp.l: Thy evil Spirit Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why com'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ghoſt.
sp.l: To tell thee thou ſhalt ſee me at Philippi.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Well: then I ſhall ſee thee again?

sp.speaker: Ghoſt.
sp.l: I, at Philippi.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why I will ſee thee at Philippi then:
Now I have taken Heart thou vaniſheſt.
Ill Spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.
Boy, Lucius, Varrus, Claudio, Sirs: Awake:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The Strings, my Lord, are falſe.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: He thinks he ſtill is at his Inſtrument.
Lucius, awake.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Did'ſt thou dream Lucius, that thou ſo cryed'ſt out?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord, I do not know that I did cry.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Yes that thou didſt: Didſt thou ſee any thing?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Sleep again Lucius: Sirra Claudio, Fellow,
Thou: Awake.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why did you ſo cry out Sirs, in your Sleep?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Die we, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I: ſaw you any thing?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: No, my Lord, I ſaw nothing.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Nor I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Go, and commend me to my Brother Caſſius:
Bid him ſet on his Powers betimes before,
And we will follow.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: It ſhall be done my Lord.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Octavius, Antony, and their Army.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Now Antony, our hopes are anſwered,
You ſaid the Enemy would not come down,
But keep the Hills and upper Regions:
It proves not ſo: their Battles are at hand,
They mean to warn us at Philippi here:
Anſwering before we do demand of them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tut, I am in their Boſoms, and I know
Wherefore they do it: They could be content
To viſit other places, and come down
With fearful Bravery: thinking by this Face
To faſten in our Thoughts that they have Courage;
But 'tis not ſo.

sp.speaker: Meſ.
sp.l: Prepare you Generals,
The Enemy comes on in gallant ſhew:
Their bloody Sign of Battel is hung out,
And ſomething to be done immediately.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Octavius, lead your Battail ſoftly on
Upon the left hand of the even Field.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Upon the right hand I, keep thou the left.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why do you croſs me in this Exigent?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: I do not croſs you; but I will do ſo.

div.stage: Drum. Enter Brutus, Caſſius, and their Army.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: They ſtand, and would have Parley:

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: Stand faſt Titinius we muſt out and talk.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Mark Antony, ſhall we give ſign of Battle?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No Caeſar, we will anſwer on their Charge.
Make forth, the Generals would have ſome Words.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Stir not untill the Signal.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Words before Blows: is it ſo Countrymen?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Not that we love Words better, as you do.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Good Words are better-than bad Strokes Octavius.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: In your bad Strokes Brutus, you give good Words,
Witneſs the hole you made in Caeſars heart,
Crying long live, Hail Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: The poſture of your blows are yet unknown;
But for your words, they rob the Hibla Bees
And leave them Hony-leſs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not ſtingleſs too.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O yes, and ſoundleſs too.
For you have ſtoln their buzzing Antony,
And very wiſely threat before you ſting.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Villains: you did not ſo, when your vile daggers
Hackt one another in the ſides of Caeſar.
You ſhew'd your teeths like Apes,
And fawn'd like Hounds,
And bow'd like Bondmen, kiſſing Caeſars feet;
Whil'ſt damned Caska, like a Curr, behind
Strook Caeſar on the neck. O you Flatterers.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Flaterers? Now Brutus thank your ſelf,
This tongue had not offended ſo to day,
If Caſsius might have rul'd.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Come, come, the cauſe. If arguing make us ſweat,
The proof of it will turn to redder drops:
Look, I draw a Sword againſt Conſpirators,
When think you that the Sword goes up again?
Never till Caeſars three and thirty wounds
Be well aveng'd; or till another Caeſar
Have added ſlaughter to the Sword of Traitors.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Caeſar, thou canſt not dye by Traitors hands,
Unleſs thou bring'ſt them with thee.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: So I hope:
I was not born to dye on Brutus Sword.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O if thou wer't the Nobleſt of the Strain,
Young-man, thou could'ſt not dye more honourable.

sp.speaker: Caſsi.
sp.l: A peeviſh School-boy, worthleſs of ſuch Honour,
Joyn'd with a Masker, and a Reveller.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Old Caſsius ſtill.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Come Antony: away:
Defiance Traitors, hurl we in your teeth.
If you dare fight to day, come to the Field,
If not, when you have ſtomacks.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: Why now blow wind, ſwell Billow,
And ſwim Bark:
The Storm is up, and all is on the hazard.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Ho Lucillius, hark, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Meſſal.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: What ſays my General?

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Meſſala, this is my Birth-day: as this very day
Was Caſsius born. Give me thy hand Meſſala:
Be thou my witneſs, that againſt my will
(As Pompey was) am I compell'd to ſet
Upon one Battel all our Liberties.
You know, that I held Epicurus ſtrong,
And his Opinion: Now I change my mind,
And partly credit things that do preſage.
Coming from Sardis, on our former Enſign
Two mighty Eagles fell, and there they pearch'd,
Gorging and feeding from our Souldiers hands,
Who to Philippi here conſorted us:
This Morning are they fled away, and gone,
And in their ſteads, do Ravens, Crows, and Kites
Fly o're our heads, and downward look on us
As we were ſickly prey; their ſhadows ſeem
A Canopy moſt fatall, under which
Our Army lies, ready to give up the Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Believe not ſo.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: I but believe it partly,
For I am freſh of ſpirit, and reſolv'd
To meet all perils, very conſtantly.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Even ſo Lucillius.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Now moſt Noble Brutus,
The Gods to day ſtand friendly, that we may
Lovers in peace, lead on our days to Age.
But ſince the affayrs of men reſt ſtill incertain,
Let's reaſon with the worſt that may befall.
If we do loſe this Battail, then is this
The very laſt time we ſhall ſpeak together:
What are you then determined to do?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Even by the rule of that Philoſophy,
By which I did blame Cato, for the death
Which he did give himſelf, I know not how:
But I do find it Cowardly, and vile,
For fear of what might fall, ſo to prevent
The time of life, arming my ſelf with patience,
To ſtay the providence of ſome high Powers,
That govern us below.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Then, if we loſe this Battail,
You are contented to be led in Triumph
Thorow the Streets of Rome.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: No Caſsius, no:
Think not, thou Noble Roman,
That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome,
He bears too great a mind. But this ſame day
Muſt end that work, the Ides of March begun.
And whether we ſhall meet again, I know not:
Therefore our everlaſting farewell take:
For ever, and for ever, farewell Caſsius,
If we do meet again, why we ſhall ſmile:
If not, why then this parting was well made.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: For ever, and for ever, farewell Brutus:
If we do meet again, we'll ſmile indeed;
If not, 'tis true, this parting was well made.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why then lead on. O that a man might know
The end of this days buſineſs, e're it come:
But it ſufficeth, that the day will end,
And then the end is known. Come ho, away.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Ride, ride Meſſala, ride and give theſe Bills
Unto the Legions, on the other ſide.
Let them ſet on at once: for I perceive
But cold demeanor in Octavio's wing:
And ſudden puſh gives them the overthrow:
Ride, ride Meſſala, let them all come down.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: O look Titinius, look the Villains flye:
My ſelf have to mine own turn'd Enemy;
This Enſign here of mine was turning back,
I ſlew the Coward, and did take it from him.

sp.speaker: Titi.
sp.l: O Caſſius, Brutus gave the word too early,
Who having ſome advantage on Octavius,
Took it too eagerly: his Souldiers fell to ſpoil,
Whil'ſt we by Antony are all inclos'd.

sp.speaker: Pind.
sp.l: Fly further off my Lord: fly further off,
Mark Antony is in your Tents my Lord:
Fly therefore Noble Caſsius, fly far off,

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: This Hill is far enough. Look, look Titinius
Are thoſe my Tents where I perceive the fire?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: They are, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Titinius, if thou loveſt me,
Mo ••• thou my horſe, and hide thy ſpurs in him,
Till he have brought thee up to yonder Troops
And here again, that I may reſt aſſur'd
Whether yond Troops, are Friend or Enemy

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: I will be here again, even with a thought.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Go Pindarus, get higher on that hill,
My ſight was ever thick: regard Titinius,
And tell me what thou not'ſt about the Field,
This day I breathed firſt, Time is come round,
And where I did begin, there ſhall I end,
My life is run his compaſs. Sirrah, what news?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Above. O my Lord.

sp.speaker: Caſſi.
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Pind.
sp.l: Titinius is encloſed round about
With horſemen, that make to him on the Spurr,
Yet he ſpurs on. Now they are almoſt on him:
Now Titinius. Now ſome light: O he lights too;
Hee's tane. Shout.
And hark, they ſhout for joy.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Come down, behold no more:
O Coward that I am, to live ſo long,
To ſee my beſt Friend tane before my face.
Come hither ſirrah: In Parthia did I take thee Priſoner,
And then I ſwore thee, ſaving of thy life,
That whatſoever I did bid thee do,
Thou ſhould'ſt attempt it. Come now, keep thine Oath,
Now be a Free-man, and with this good Sword
That ran through Caeſars bowels, ſearch this boſom.
Stand not to anſwer: Here, take thou the Hilts,
And when my face is cover'd, as 'tis now,
Guide thou the Sword—Caeſar, thou art reveng'd,
Even with the Sword that kill'd thee.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: So, I am free,
Yet would not ſo have been
Durſt I have done my will. O Caſsius,
Far from this Country Pindarus ſhall run,
Where never Roman ſhall take note of him.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: It is but change, Titinius: for Octavius
Is overthrown by Noble Brutus power,
As Caſſius Legions are by Antony.

sp.speaker: Titin.
sp.l: Theſe tydings will well comfort Caſſius.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Where did you leave him.

sp.speaker: Titin.
sp.l: All diſconſolate,
With Pindarus his Bondman, on this Hill.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Is not that he that lyes upon the ground?

sp.speaker: Titin.
sp.l: He lies not like the Living. O my heart!

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Is not that he?

sp.speaker: Titin.
sp.l: No, this was he Meſſala,
But Caſſius is no more. O ſetting Sun:
As in thy red Rays thou doeſt ſink to night;
So in his red blood Caſsius day is ſet.
The Sun of Rome is ſet. Our day is gone,
Clowds, Dews, and Dangers come; our deeds are done:
Miſtruſt of my ſucceſs hath done this deed.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Miſtruſt of good ſucceſs hath done this deed.
O hateful Error, Melancholies Child:
Why do'ſt thou ſhew to the apt thoughts of men
The things that are not? O Error ſoon conceiv'd,
Thou never com'ſt unto a happy birth,
But kil'ſt the Mother that engendred thee.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: What Pindarus? Where art thou, Pindarus?

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Seek him Titinius, whil'ſt I go to meet
The Noble Brutus, thruſting this report
Into his ears; I may ſay thruſting it:
For piercing Steel, and Darts invenomed,
Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus,
As tydings of this ſight.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Hye you Meſſala,
And I will ſeek for Pindarus the while:
Why did'ſt thou ſend me forth brave Caſsius?
Did I not meet thy Friends, and did not they
Put on my Brows this wreath of Victory,
And bid me give it thee? Did'ſt thou not hear their ſhowts?
Alas, thou haſt miſconſtrued every thing.
But hold thee, take this Garland on thy Brow,
Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I
Will do his bidding. Brutus, come apace,
And ſee how I regarded Caius Caſsius:
By your leave Gods: This is a Romans part,
Come Caſsius Sword, and find Titinius heart.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Brutus, Meſſala, young Cato, Stato, Volumnius, and Lucillius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Where, where Meſſala, doth his body lye?

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Loe yonder, and Titinius mourning it.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Titinius face is upward.

sp.speaker: Cato.
sp.l: He is ſlain.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O Julius Caeſar, thou art mighty yet,
Thy Spirit walks abroad, and turns our Swords
In our own proper Entrails.

sp.speaker: Cato.
sp.l: Brave Titinius.
Look where he have not Crown'd dead Caſſius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Are yet two Romans living ſuch as theſe?
The laſt of all the Romans, far thee well:
It is impoſſible, that ever Rome
Should breed thy fellow. Friends I own mo tears
To this dead man, then you ſhall ſee me pay.
I ſhall find time, Caſſius: I ſhall find time.
Come therefore, and to Tharſus ſend his body,
His Funerals ſhall not be in our Camp,
Leſt it diſcomfort us. Lucillius come,
And come young Cato, let us to the Field,
Labio and Flavio ſet our Battails on,
'Tis three a clock, and Romans yet e're night,
We ſhall try Fortune in a ſecond fight.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Brutus, Meſſala, Cato, Lucillius, and Flavius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Yet Country-men: O yet, hold up your heads.

sp.speaker: Cato.
sp.l: What Baſtard doth not? Who will go with me?
I will proclaim my name about the Field.
I am the Son of Marcus Cato, ho.
A Foe to Tyrants, and my Countrys Friend.
I am the Son of Marcus Cato, ho.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I,
Brutus my Countrys Friend: Know me for Brutus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O young and Noble Cato, art thou down?
Why now thou dyeſt, as bravely as Titinius,
And may'ſt be honour'd being Cato's Son.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Yield, or thou dieſt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Only I yield to die:
There is ſo much, that thou wilt kill me ſtraight:
Kill Brutus, and be honour'd in his death.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: We muſt not: A Noble Priſoner.

sp.speaker: 2. Sold.
sp.l: Room ho: tell Antony, Brutus is tane.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.l: I'le tell the news. Here comes the Generall,
Brutus is tane, Brutus is tane my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Safe Antony, Brutus is ſafe enough:
I dare aſſure thee, that no Enemy
Shall ever take alive the Noble Brutus:
The Gods defend him from ſo great a ſhame,
When you do find him, or alive, or dead;
He will be found like Brutus, like himſelf.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is not Brutus friend, but I aſſure you,
A prize no leſs in worth; keep this man ſafe,
Give him all kindneſs. I had rather have
Such men my Friends, then Enemies. Go on,
And ſee where Brutus be alive or dead,
And bring us word, unto Octavius Tent:
How every thing is chanc'd.

div.stage: Enter Brutus, Dardanius, Clitus, Strato, and Volumnius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Come poor remains of friends, reſt on this Rock.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: Statillius ſhew'd the Torch-light, but my Lord,
He came not back: he is or tane, or ſlain.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Sit thee down, Clitus: ſlaying is the word,
It is a deed in faſhion. Hark thee, Clitus.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: What I, my Lord? No, not for all the World.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Peace then, no words.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: I'le rather kill my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Hark thee, Dardanius.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.l: Shall I do ſuch a deed?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: O Dardanius.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.l: O Clitus.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: What ill requeſt did Brutus make to thee?

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.l: To kill him, Clitus: look he meditates.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: Now is that Noble Veſſel full of grief,
That it runs over even at his eyes.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Come hither, good Volumnius, liſt a word.

sp.speaker: Volum.
sp.l: What ſays my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why this, Volumnius:
The Ghoſt of Caeſar hath appear'd to me
Two ſeveral times by Night: at Sardis, once;
And this laſt Night, here in Philippi Fields:
I know my hour is come.

sp.speaker: Volum.
sp.l: Not ſo, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Nay, I am ſure it is, Volumnius.
Thou ſee'ſt the World, Volumnius, how it goes,
Our Enemies have beat us to the Pit:
It is more worthy, to leap in our ſelves,
Then tarry till they puſh us. Good Volumnius,
Thou know'ſt, that we two went to School together:
Even for that our love of old, I prethee
Hold thou my Sword Hilts, whileſt I run on it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: That's not an Office for a friend, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Fly, fly my Lord, there is no tarrying here.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Farewell to you, and you, and you Volumnius.
Strato, thou haſt been all this while aſleep:
Farewell to thee, to Strato, Countrymen:
My heart doth joy, that yet in all my life,
I found no man, but he was true to me.
I ſhall have glory by this loſing day
More then Octavius, and Mark Antony,
By this vile Conqueſt ſhall attain unto▪
So fare you well at once, for Brutus tongue▪
Hath almoſt ended his lives Hiſtory:
Night hangs upon mine eyes, my Bones would reſt,
That have but labour'd, to attain this hour.

div.stage: Alarum. Cry within, Fly, fly, fly.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Fly my Lord, fly.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Hence: I will follow:
I prethee Strato, ſtay thou by thy Lord,
Thou art a Fellow of a good reſpect:
Thy life hath had ſome ſmatch of Honour in it,
Hold then my Sword, and turn away thy face,
While I do run upon it. Wilt thou Strato?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Give me your hand firſt. Fare you well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Farewell good Strato.—Caeſar, now be ſtill,
Ikill'd not thee with half ſo good a will.

div.stage: Alarum. Retreat. Enter Antony, Octavius, Meſſala, Lucillius, and the Army.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: What man is that?

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: My Maſters man. Strato, where is thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Free from the Bondage you are in Meſſala,
The Conquerors can but make a fire of him:
For Brutus only overcame himſelf,
And no man elſe hath Honour by his death.

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: So Brutus ſhould be found. I thank thee Brutus
That thou haſt prov'd Lucillius ſaying true,

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: All that ſerv'd Brutus, I will entertain them.
Fellow, wilt thou beſtow thy time with me?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I, if Meſſala will prefer me to you.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Do ſo, good Meſſala.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: How dyed my Maſter Strato?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I held the Sword, and he did run on it.

sp.speaker: Meſſa.
sp.l: Octavius then take him to follow thee,
That did the lateſt ſervice to my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This was the Nobleſt Roman of them all:
All the Conſpirators ſave only he,
Did that they did in envy of great Caeſar:
He, only in a generall honeſt thought,
And common good to all, made one of them.
His life was gentle, and the Elements
So mixt in him, that Nature might ſtand up,
And ſay to all the World; This was a man.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: According to his Vertue, let us uſe him
With all Reſpect, and Rites of Buriall.
Within my Tent his bones to night ſhall lye,
Moſt like a Souldier ordered Honourably:
So call the Field to reſt, and let's away,
To part the glories of this happy day.
